Dictionary.gml:description: Dictionary enumerating the values for the element "property_class" of the object "Property" used within the Test and Monitor DIGGS features at these XPath locations: diggs:Diggs/diggs:measurement/diggs:Test/diggs:outcome/diggs:TestResult/diggs:results/diggs:ResultSet/diggs:parameters/diggs:PropertyParameters/diggs:properties/diggs:Property/diggs:propertyClass, and diggs:Diggs/diggs:measurement/diggs:Monitor/diggs:reading/diggs:Reading/diggs:outcome/diggs:MonitorResult/diggs:results/diggs:ResultSet/diggs:parameters/diggs:PropertyParameters/diggs:properties/diggs:Property/diggs:propertyClass, and These values serve to define the "results" of geotechnical and environmental tests and monitoring activities that result from test procedures and monitoring sensors, but that may not specifically bound to the procedures that produce the results.diggs:Diggs/diggs:measurement/diggs:Monitor/diggs:reading/diggs:Reading/diggs:sensor/diggs:Sensor/diggs:detector/diggs:Detector/diggs:measurand. These values serve to define the "results" of geotechnical and environmental tests and monitoring activities that result from test procedures and monitoring sensors, but that may not specifically bound to the procedures that produce the results.

Definition.gml:description: The Aggregate Abrasion Value is a measure of the resistance of aggregate to surface wear by abrasion.
The Aggregate Crushing Value provides a relative measure of the resistance of an aggregate to crushing under a gradually applied compressive load.
The Elongation Index of an aggregate is defined as the percentage by weight of particles whose greatest dimension (length) is 1.8 times their mean dimension.
The Flakiness Index is defined as the percentage by weight of aggregate particles whose least dimension is less than 0.6 times their mean size.
The Aggregate Impact Value represents the resistance to impact of aggregates and is measured as percentage of aggregates passing to the total weight of the sample.
The actual measured loss (difference between the original weight and the final weight of the test sample), expressed as a percentage of the original weight of the test sample.
The loss (difference between the original weight and the final weight of the test sample), expressed as an integer.
The actual measured loss (difference between the original weight and the final weight of the test sample), expressed as an integer percentage of the original weight of the test sample.
The Polished Stone Value is a measure of the resistance of an aggregate to polishing.

The Water Absorption test produces a water content value and gives an idea of strength of aggregate. Aggregates having more water absorption are more porous in nature and are generally considered unsuitable unless they are found to be acceptable based on strength, impact, and hardness tests.
Total mass (of solids and water) divided by total volume
California Bearing Ratio is the ratio, expressed as a percentage, of the measured pressure for site soils divided by pressure to achieve equal penetration on a standard soil.

The Chalk Crushing Value is determined by using the chalk impact crushing test, which measures the rate at which a sample of chalk lumps crushes under impacts from a freefalling rammer. The chalk crushing value can be used, together with the saturation moisture content of the intact chalk lumps, to classify chalk in relation to its behavior as a freshly placed fill material. The test procedure is described for a single sample of chalk lumps, but normal procedure should be to calculate the mean value derived from six such tests on representative samples.
represents the total amount of clay sized particles (<2 microns) in a test samples
represents the total amount of clay sized particles (<5 microns) in a test samples
The horizontal coefficient of consolidation as derived from the dissipation test data from a cone penetration or dilatometer test.
The vertical coefficient of consolidation as derived from a one-dimensional consolidation test in the lab.
A coefficient describing the degree of curvature of the grain size distribution. Defined as (d30)^2/((d60)*(d10))
The ratio of horizontal earth pressure to vertical pressure for a sample in the field.
Definition.gml:identifier: coefficient of earth pressure, in situ

Definition.gml:description: The ratio of D60/D10
represents the total amount of <1 micron size particles in a test samples

Result from a Consolidation Test. This test is performed to determine the magnitude and rate of void ratio change for a laterally confined soil specimen that is subjected to different vertical pressures. From the measured data, the consolidation curve (pressure-void ratio relationship) can be plotted. This specific value is used for a specific portion of the log vertical pressure - void ratio curve to signify virgin compression. The one-dimension consolidation curve can be used to determine other values (e.g., the recompression index (slope of recompression curve) and the preconsolidation pressure (or maximum past pressure) of the soil).
The time it takes for a compressional wave to traverse a fixed distance; reciprocal of Compressional_Velocity.
Result of axial compression test using unconfined compression

The consistency index (CI) indicates the consistency (firmness) of a soil. It is calculated as CI = (LL-W)/(LL-PL), where W is the existing water content. Soil at the liquid limit will have a consistency index of 0, while soil at the plastic limit will have a consistency index of 100.
measure of slope of stress-strain curve when specimen is confined. Usually the result from a 1-D consolidation test.
Grain diameter corresponding to 10 percent passing. Intermediate value used to report other results.
Grain diameter corresponding to 30 percent passing. Intermediate value used to report other results.
Grain diameter corresponding to 50 percent passing. Intermediate value used to report other results.
Grain diameter corresponding to 60 percent passing. Intermediate value used to report other results.
Volume of water divided by the volume of voids, expressed as a percentage
Mass of solids divided by total volume
the value of pore pressure measured in the field after dissipation of induced excess pore pressure. Could also be from CPTu test

Flame Ionization Detector Test detects total concentrations of organic gases and vapors. Gases and vapors are ionized in a flame; a current is produced in proportion to the number of carbon atoms present. Reported result can be in various units of measure, depending upon specific equipment used.
measure of frictional resistance of soil. Ratio of shear strength to normal stress
ratio of sleeve resistance to tip resistance
Test establishes the degree of frost-susceptibility of unbound sub-base and base materials for pavements.

The intensity of natural gamma-ray radiation emitted from formations containing radioactive elements, such as Potassium, Thorium, and Uranium. Measured according to API specifications or as counts per time
Total mass (of solids and water) divided by total volume, as measured insitu
A measure of the resisting power of a specified material to the flow of an electric current.
The liquid limit (LL) is the water content at which a soil changes from plastic to liquid behavior.
Liquid limit determined if sample required oven drying before test

The liquidity index (LI) is used for scaling the natural water content of a soil sample to the limits. It can be calculated as a ratio of difference between natural water content, plastic limit, and liquid limit: LI=(W-PL)/(LL-PL) where W is the natural water content.

This is a result of a compaction test. It is defined as the maximum dry unit weight that is measured when a specific type and amount of energy is used for the compaction test. This is also the value of the compacted dry unit weight when the soil is at the optimum moisture content.

The Moisture Condition Value (MCV) is determined from a moisture condition test, a physical test indicating how much compactive effort is needed to compact a sample of soil at a particular moisture content.
Total mass (of solids and water) divided by total volume
Value from Standard Penetration Test (SPT) to define advancement in terms of blows required to drive a specific sampler I foot into the soil using a hammer that provides a specific impact energy.
Not typically a number or term we use

Calculated value that corrects the value of the Standard Penetration Blow Count (N), to account for energy of the hammer (specifically normalized to 60% energy) and specific overburden conditions (specifically to an overburden stress of 1 ton per square foot).
Also referred to as moisture content, this is the mass of water divided by the mass of the solids, expressed as a percentage. Use of this parameter is for natural conditions.

This is a result of a compaction test. It is defined as the moisture content at the maximum dry unit weight as measured when a specific type and amount of energy is used for the compaction test. This is also the value of the compaction moisture content when the soils achieves the maximum dry unit weight.
Definition.gml:identifier: moisture content at maximum dry density

Definition.gml:description: A calculation that reflects the maximum past consolidation test that the in situ soil has been subjected to compared to the current vertical overburden stress on the sample in the field. This value is usually measured from the one-dimensional consolidation tests. Often referenced as the parameter to track the stress history.
P waves (primary waves) are compressional waves that are longitudinal in nature.

A-Reading corrected for the DA membrane stiffness at 0.05 mm expansion, the 0.05 mm expansion itself and the gauge pressure deviation from zero. This corrected pressure is referred to as p0. This is an intermediate result from a flat plate dilatometer test.

B-Reading corrected for the DB membrane stiffness at 1.10 mm expansion and the gauge pressure deviation from zero. This corrected pressure is referred to as p1. This is an intermediate result from a flat plate dilatometer test.

C-Reading corrected for the DA membrane stiffness at 0.05 mm expansion and the gauge pressure deviation from zero. This corrected pressure is referred to as p2. This is an intermediate result from a flat plate dilatometer test.
air of a unit volume of the impermeable portion of aggregate to the weight in air
of an equal volume of distilled water, both at a stated temperature.

A measure of the shear strength of the soil when no volume change is allowed during the tests. The value can be measured in the lab and in the field. In both cases, the value can be calculated from different tests.

A measure of the shear strength of the soil when no volume change is allowed during the tests. The value can be measured in the lab and in the field. In both cases, the value can be calculated from different tests.
The percentage of particles that pass through the #200 sieve
The percentage of particles that are retained on the #4 or larger sieves
The rate at which water flows through a soi in the horizontal direction is proportional to the hydraulic gradient and is expressed by Darcy's Law
Coefficient of permeability, measuring rate of horizontal flow
Coefficient of permeability, measuring rate of vertical flow
The measure of the pH of soil or liquid
Measures volatile organic compounds and other gases, expressed in parts per million.
The plastic limit (PL) is the water content where soil transitions between brittle and plastic behavior.

The plasticity index (PI) is a measure of the plasticity of a soil. The plasticity index is a measure of the range of water contents where the soil exhibits plastic properties. The PI is the difference between the liquid limit and the plastic limit (PI = LL-PL). (Soils with a high PI tend to be clay, those with a lower PI tend to be silt, and those with a PI of 0 (non-plastic) tend to have little or no silt or clay.)
The Point Load Test produces the Point Load Test Index (Is50), which can be correlated with the uniaxial compressive strength (UCS) of rock.
Ratio of the transverse contraction of a body to its longitudinal extension when stretched. Typical values in minerals are from 0.15 to 0.3 (Carbonates:0.15, Sandstones:0.2, Shales:0.25).
measured pore pressure from transducer

Result from a Consolidation Test. This test is performed to determine the magnitude and rate of void ratio change for a laterally confined soil specimen that is subjected to different vertical pressures. From the measured data, the consolidation curve (pressure-void ratio relationship) can be plotted. This specific value is used for a specific portion of the log vertical pressure - void ratio curve to signify the largest value of stress that sample has experienced before the performance of this test. It is a calculation results usually obtained by a construction technique using laboratory test results.

Result from a Consolidation Test. This test is performed to determine the magnitude and rate of void ratio change for a laterally confined soil specimen that is subjected to different vertical pressures. From the measured data, the consolidation curve (pressure-void ratio relationship) can be plotted. This specific value is used for a specific portion of the log vertical pressure - void ratio curve to signify a response due to the unloading and reloading of a sample that is on the virgin curve.
The density of a granular specimen relative to its maximum and minimum density (or void ratio)

A measure of the shear strength of the soil when no volume change is allowed during the tests. The value can be measured in the lab and in the field. In both cases, the value can be calculated from different tests.
From Mohr-Coulomb failure criteria, this is the y-axis intercept of the failure envelope at the residual (or large deformation)strength
the strength measured after large deformations. Again this value is specifically calculated as the ratio of the strength to normal stress.
Rock porosity
S waves (secondary waves) are shear waves that are transverse in nature.

The Schmidt Hardness Test utilizes a hammer mass launched against an impact plunger. The amount of hammer mass rebound depends on the hardness of the test piece. This rebound amount is then shown on a scale of 10 to 100.
the ratio of the strength of the soil in the undisturbed state to that of the soil in the remolded state.
Shear modulus, denoted by G, is defined as the ratio of shear stress to the shear strain.

Acoustic slowness of a shear wave (Vs); reciprocal of Shear_Velocity; a shear wave is a type of seismic wave in which the particle motion is perpendicular to the direction of propagation; also called S-wave or secondary wave.

The velocity of a shear wave (Vs); a shear wave is a type of seismic wave in which the particle motion is perpendicular to the direction of propagation in a horizontal plane ; also called S-wave or secondary wave.

The height of the rebound travel of the Scleroscope hammer is measured on a graduated scale. The scale of the rebound is arbitrarily chosen and consists on Shore units, divided into 100 parts, which represent the average rebound from pure hardened high-carbon steel. The scale is continued higher than 100 to include metals having greater hardness.
The shrinkage limit (SL) is the water content below which a soil undergoes no further volume change.
The ratio of a given volume change expressed as a percentage of the dry volume to the corresponding change in water content above the shrinkage limit.

The Slake Durability Classification is a qualitative term that predicts the long-term durability of the rock specimens, to establish weathering and degradation characteristics of each rock type, and to assess the impact of water on the rock degradation.

The Slake Durability Index predicts the long-term durability of the rock specimens, to establish weathering and degradation characteristics of each rock type, and to assess the impact of water on the rock degradation.
measure of stress measured on sleeve of cone during penetration
The amount of organic matter in a soil that derives from peat, organic muck, plant material such as wood, roots, grass, or carbonaceous maTerials such as lignite, coal, etc.
Soil suction value
Sonic porosity
Porosity calculated using the acoustic slowness measurement from a sonic log.

The apparent specific gravity is designated Ga and is the ratio of the weight in air of a unit volume of the impermeable portion of aggregate to the weight in air of an equal volume of distilled water, both at a stated temperature. The impermeable portion of a porous material, such as most large soil grains, includes the solid material plus impermeable pores or voids within the particles.

The bulk specific gravity is designated Gm and is the ratio of the weight in air of a unit volume of aggregate (including permeable and impermeable voids in the particles, but not the voids between the particles) to the weight of an equal volume of distilled water at a stated temperature.

The specific gravity of solids (Gs) is the bulk density of the solid particles relative to the density of water. It is a required parameter to assess void ratio. Its value is a function of the mineralogy of the solid particles. It is commonly assumed by geotechnical engineers.

Also called self potential, is a naturally occurring electric potential difference in the Earth, measured by an electrode relative to a fixed reference electrode. Spontaneous potentials are usually caused by charge separation in clay or other minerals, due to presence of semi-permeable interface impeding the diffusion of ions through the pore space of rocks, or by natural flow of a conducting fluid through the rocks.
Tests resistance to degradation of aggregates.
The force tending to cause extension of a body, as experienced in a cable, rope, string, etc.
Thrust force required to advance the dilatometer to the test depth. This force is exclusive of soil or other friction along the push rods. This thrust is referred to as qd.
measure of stress measured at tip of cone during penetration

Unit weight of a soil mass is the ratio of the total weight of soil to the total volume of soil.
Unit Weight, g, is usually determined in the laboratory by measuring the weight and volume of a relatively undisturbed soil sample obtained from a ring of specific dimensions . Measuring unit weight of soil in the field may consist of a sand cone test, water replacement test, or nuclear densiometer.
The soil classification for the bulk sediment determined from a Particle Size Text
The soil classification for the sediment fraction passing the No. 40 (425 micron) screen and tested for liquid limit and plastic limit
The decrease in volume of a soil mass when the water content is reduced from a given percentage to the shrinkage limit and which is expressed as percentage of dry volume of the soil mass.

The tangent modulus of the initial, linear portion of a stress-strain curve for material in axial compression or tension is called Young's modulus, also known as the tensile (compression) modulus. It is defined as the ratio of the uniaxial stress over the uniaxial strain in the range of stress in which Hooke's Law holds. It is often calculated using theory of elasticity from other tests.
